title: How do we factorize X²+4x+3+mx+3m? - Quora

response.answer_text: Well, try using quadratic formula to factor [math]x^2+4x+3 [/math]to get [math](x+1)(x+3)[/math]. Then, [math]x^2+4x+3+mx+3m = (x+1)(x+3)+m(x+3)[/math]. Now, since [math](x+3)[/math] is the common between two terms, thus it equals [math](x+3)(x+1+m)[/math]. Now, the factors of this equation is [math]x=-3[/math] or [math]x=-m-1[/math].

Regrouping, [math]x^2+(4+m)x+(3+3m)[/math]. The factors of 3+3m are 3 and 1+m. The sum of these factors is 4+m, which is the coefficient of the middle term. Hence, this is factored as [math](x+3)(x+1+m)[/math]
